metadata.title: Three Questions Business Leaders Should Be Asking About Apple’s New Machine Learning Kit | by Jonathan Balaban | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Three Questions Business Leaders Should Be Asking About Apple’s New Machine Learning Kit
metadata.description: At the end of 2017, Apple made a splash in the machine learning domain when it released Turi Create, an open source package that makes it easier for developers to put the power of machine learning…

all_paragraphs: At the end of 2017, Apple made a splash in the machine learning domain when it released Turi Create, an open source package that makes it easier for developers to put the power of machine learning into their apps. The company’s announcement claimed Turi Create would allow users to “focus on tasks instead of algorithms.” Let’s face it: that’s music to the ears of business leaders with limited time and resources!

Now that the data scientists and software developers of the world have had some time to absorb the news and start working with Turi Create, let’s break down how it could become a game-changer for your business — even if your business is still getting up to speed on the latest in AI.
1. So what is Turi Create, anyway?

Turi Create (TC) is a machine learning toolkit that lets you implement custom machine learning models for your app by inserting a few lines of code. Its strengths, and what distinguishes it from other kits, are its speed, efficiency, and unique features (like GPU acceleration) that either don’t exist or are early stage in competing packages.

2. OK, I get the basics. So what is Apple actually doing with TC?

Apple’s acquisition of Turi, followed just a year later by the release of Turi Create, shows the company is getting serious about building out its machine learning capabilities. It’s not alone in this space, of course, as companies ranging from giants like Google to small start-ups are all competing in the “big data” domain.

Unlike some other tech firms, however, Apple prides itself on respecting customers’ data privacy, so its focus remains on improving the general user experience. Here are some ways the Cupertino team is using TC right now in its products and services:

As Apple continues to expand its used of TC, you’ll want to stay informed about the latest applications so you can brainstorm how to develop analogous solutions for your own business challenges. One of the best ways to do that is to keep an eye on Apple’s regularly-updated machine learning blog.
3. Those are some pretty interesting applications, but how can I start thinking about using TC to benefit my business?

Here’s the good news: because Turi Create does much of the work for you, you don’t need to develop advanced machine learning skills to take advantage of its cutting-edge techniques. In addition, because TC is open source, it’s more than likely you’ll be able to find existing models created by third party developers to help you with your business problems.

Your task lies in creatively applying TC and its open source models to your unique data sets. For example, if your business sells a subscription service or licenses software, TC’s extensive suite of classification models may determine which customers are more likely to turn over, or “churn”. You can then incentivize those customers to renew, or determine if another product fits their needs.

Another use case: if your firm provides a number of products or services — and you have data about your customer base — you can implement TC’s recommender system to quantify customers’ interest and prioritize which new items you market or offer. Right now, these models power Amazon and eBay’s “recommended for you” listings, Spotify’s music playlist curation, and GrubHub’s vendor spotlights.

Finally, if you run a medical business that collects heart, brain, or activity metrics using on-body sensors, you can use TC’s activity classifier to ingest data from devices like gyroscopes, thermostats, and more. The model will then predict what kind of exercise, chronic condition, or medical emergency may be happening. In addition to the medical field, you can apply models to cybersecurity, engineering, and any field where patterns can be deduced from noisy data.

Thinking about these examples, you may begin to understand how you can head down the path toward using your own data in similar ways. Now that you’ve started asking about (1) the basics of Turi Create, (2) how Apple is using the platform, and (3) how you might creatively apply it to your work, you’re three steps closer to figuring out how TC can open up a new world of possibilities for your business.
